1 STAT 515 Final Project Presentation Script - GREG SEAN

1.1 Transition from Rupesh (30 seconds)

GREG: “Thank you, Rupesh. We’ve seen that overtime work and career stagnation are major attrition drivers. But do these factors affect all departments equally? That’s what our third research question addresses.

1.2 Question 3: Department-Stratified Satisfaction Analysis (5-6 minutes)

GREG: “Our third research question asks: Do satisfaction variables predict attrition differently across departments? Should HR implement department-specific retention strategies?

1.2.1 Why Stratify by Department?

Organizations often apply one-size-fits-all retention programs, but this ignores fundamental differences in job characteristics:

  • R&D Engineers: Creative problem-solving, collaborative projects, technical challenges
  • Sales Representatives: Client-facing, commission-driven, high-pressure targets
  • HR Professionals: People-focused, policy implementation, organizational support

These distinct roles likely have different satisfaction drivers and attrition patterns.

1.2.2 Key Variables (Q3)

  • JobSatisfaction: Satisfaction with role/responsibilities (1-4 scale)
  • EnvironmentSatisfaction: Satisfaction with work environment (1-4 scale)
  • RelationshipSatisfaction: Satisfaction with colleagues/manager (1-4 scale)
  • Department: R&D, Sales, or HR

1.2.3 Methodology: Stratified Logistic Regression

We fit separate logistic regression models for each department:

Model: Attrition ~ JobSatisfaction + EnvironmentSatisfaction + RelationshipSatisfaction
Separate models for: R&D, Sales, HR

This approach allows: - Different coefficient estimates per department - Department-specific effect sizes - Tailored insights for targeted interventions

1.2.4 Department Breakdown

Research & Development (R&D): - Sample size: 961 employees (65% of dataset) - Attrition rate: 13.8% (lowest) - Most stable department

Sales: - Sample size: 446 employees (30% of dataset) - Attrition rate: 20.6% (highest) - Highest turnover challenge

Human Resources (HR): - Sample size: 63 employees (4% of dataset) - Attrition rate: 19.0% - Limited statistical power due to small sample

1.2.5 Key Findings (Q3)

1. R&D Department (n=961, 13.8% attrition)

All three satisfaction measures are statistically significant predictors:

  • JobSatisfaction: Coefficient = -0.512 (p < 0.001)
    • Odds Ratio = 0.60 → Each 1-point increase in job satisfaction reduces attrition odds by 40%
  • EnvironmentSatisfaction: Coefficient = -0.487 (p < 0.001)
    • Odds Ratio = 0.61 → Each 1-point increase reduces attrition odds by 39%
  • RelationshipSatisfaction: Coefficient = -0.384 (p < 0.01)
    • Odds Ratio = 0.68 → Each 1-point increase reduces attrition odds by 32%

Model Performance: AUC = 0.706

Interpretation: R&D employees are highly sensitive to satisfaction levels across all dimensions. This makes sense - engineers and scientists value intellectual stimulation (job), collaborative environment (environment), and peer relationships (relationship).

2. Sales Department (n=446, 20.6% attrition)

Only two satisfaction measures are significant:

  • JobSatisfaction: Coefficient = -0.623 (p < 0.01)
    • Odds Ratio = 0.54 → Each 1-point increase reduces attrition odds by 46%
  • EnvironmentSatisfaction: Coefficient = -0.498 (p < 0.05)
    • Odds Ratio = 0.61 → Each 1-point increase reduces attrition odds by 39%
  • RelationshipSatisfaction: Coefficient = -0.201 (p = 0.24) - NOT SIGNIFICANT

Model Performance: AUC = 0.679

Interpretation: Sales representatives care primarily about role fit (job satisfaction) and work conditions (environment), but relationships with colleagues matter less. This aligns with sales culture - individual performance, commission structures, and client relationships dominate. Internal peer relationships are secondary.

Critical Insight: Sales has the highest attrition rate (20.6%) - this department requires immediate attention.

3. HR Department (n=63, 19.0% attrition)

None of the satisfaction predictors reach statistical significance:

  • JobSatisfaction: Coefficient = -0.472 (p = 0.19)
  • EnvironmentSatisfaction: Coefficient = -0.289 (p = 0.38)
  • RelationshipSatisfaction: Coefficient = -0.156 (p = 0.66)

Model Performance: AUC = 0.682

Interpretation: The lack of significance is likely due to limited sample size (n=63). With only 12 attrition cases in HR (19% of 63), we have insufficient statistical power to detect effects. The coefficient directions are negative (protective against attrition), but confidence intervals are too wide for significance.

1.2.6 Comparative Analysis Across Departments

Coefficient Comparison (Figure 11): Our visualization shows:

  • R&D: All three coefficients are strongly negative and significant
  • Sales: Job and Environment coefficients are negative; Relationship is near zero
  • HR: All coefficients are negative but with wide confidence intervals

Model Performance Table (Table 9):

Department N Attrition Rate AIC AUC
R&D 961 13.8% 643.71 0.706
Sales 446 20.6% 355.88 0.679
HR 63 19.0% 58.23 0.682

Key Observations: 1. R&D has best model performance (highest AUC) due to large sample and clear satisfaction-attrition relationships 2. Sales has worst attrition rate (20.6%) but moderate model performance 3. HR has smallest sample, limiting both power and model reliability

1.2.7 Practical Implications (Q3)

Department-Specific Retention Strategies:

For R&D (13.8% attrition): - Focus: All-around satisfaction improvement - Actions: - Enhance project variety and technical challenges (job satisfaction) - Invest in modern tools and collaborative spaces (environment satisfaction) - Foster team-building and mentorship programs (relationship satisfaction) - Why: R&D shows significant effects across all three dimensions

For Sales (20.6% attrition - HIGHEST PRIORITY): - Focus: Role clarity and work conditions - Actions: - Realign territories and commission structures (job satisfaction) - Provide CRM tools, sales training, and support resources (environment satisfaction) - De-prioritize team-building initiatives (relationship satisfaction not significant) - Why: Sales attrition is double that of R&D; focus resources where they matter most

For HR (19.0% attrition): - Focus: Broader diagnostic needed - Actions: - Conduct qualitative exit interviews - Analyze non-satisfaction factors (compensation, career path, workload) - Consider merging with broader “professional services” category for future analysis - Why: Small sample limits quantitative insights; need qualitative data

1.3 Comprehensive Model Comparison (3-4 minutes)

GREG: “Now let’s step back and compare all eight models we’ve built across the three research questions.

1.3.1 Model Performance Summary

Model AUC Type
Random Forest (Q1) 0.777 Tree-Based
Weighted Logistic (Q2) 0.752 Logistic
LASSO Logistic (Q2) 0.747 Logistic
Unweighted Logistic (Q2) 0.732 Logistic
Stratified LR - R&D (Q3) 0.706 Stratified
Decision Tree (Q1) 0.685 Tree-Based
Stratified LR - HR (Q3) 0.682 Stratified
Stratified LR - Sales (Q3) 0.679 Stratified

1.3.2 Model Type Performance

Tree-Based Models: - Mean AUC: 0.731 - Range: 0.685 - 0.777 - Best overall performer: Random Forest

Logistic Models: - Mean AUC: 0.744 - Range: 0.732 - 0.752 - Consistent performance across variants

Stratified Models: - Mean AUC: 0.689 - Range: 0.679 - 0.706 - Lower AUC due to smaller samples per department

1.3.3 Which Model to Use When?

For Maximum Prediction Accuracy: → Use Random Forest (AUC = 0.777) - Best for automated early-warning systems - Identifies at-risk employees with highest accuracy - Deploy for production prediction tasks

For Business Interpretability: → Use Weighted Logistic Regression (AUC = 0.752) - Provides clear coefficient interpretations - “Each year without promotion increases odds by 13%” → actionable insight - Stakeholders can understand and trust the model logic

For Variable Selection: → Use LASSO (AUC = 0.747) - Automatically identifies most important predictors - Reduces 16 candidates to 14 essential variables - Good balance of performance and parsimony

For Targeted Interventions: → Use Department-Stratified Models - Different coefficients per department - Enables tailored retention programs - Lower AUC acceptable when specificity matters more than aggregate accuracy

1.4 Overall Conclusions & Recommendations (3-4 minutes)

GREG: “Let me synthesize our key findings and provide actionable recommendations.

1.4.1 Summary of Key Findings

Across all three research questions, we found:

  1. OverTime is the Single Strongest Predictor
    • 30.5% attrition for overtime workers vs. 10.4% for non-overtime
    • Appears in top predictors across multiple models
    • Effect is consistent across departments
  2. Career Stagnation Has Threshold Effects
    • Each year without promotion increases attrition odds by 13%
    • Risk accelerates non-linearly: 4+ years = critical threshold
    • Stock options provide strong protective effect
  3. Department Differences Are Substantial
    • R&D: 13.8% attrition, sensitive to all satisfaction dimensions
    • Sales: 20.6% attrition, sensitive to job/environment only
    • HR: 19.0% attrition, limited sample power
  4. Model Performance Varies by Purpose
    • Random Forest: Best accuracy (AUC = 0.777)
    • Weighted Logistic: Best interpretability (AUC = 0.752)
    • LASSO: Best parsimony (AUC = 0.747)

1.4.2 Comprehensive HR Recommendations

Priority 1: Overtime Management (Immediate - Weeks 1-4)

Current State: 30% of employees work overtime; 30.5% attrition rate in this group.

Actions: 1. Workload Monitoring Dashboard - Track weekly hours in real-time - Flag employees exceeding 45 hours for 3+ consecutive weeks - Estimated cost: $15,000 for software implementation

  1. Workload Rebalancing Protocol
    • Quarterly capacity planning meetings
    • Redistribute work across team members
    • Hire temporary contractors during peak periods
  2. Flexible Scheduling Policy
    • Allow compressed work weeks
    • Enable remote work for 2-3 days/week (reduces overtime and commute burden)

Expected Impact: Reduce overtime prevalence from 30% to 20%, preventing 35-40 annual departures.
ROI: Assuming average replacement cost of $50,000/employee, this saves $1.75M-$2M annually vs. $15K investment = 116x return.

Priority 2: Career Development Acceleration (Short-term - Months 1-6)

Current State: 15% of employees at 4+ years without promotion; 13% increased odds per year.

Actions: 1. Mandatory Career Review at Year 3 - Individual development plans - Promotion eligibility assessment - Lateral move opportunities if vertical promotion unavailable

  1. Fast-Track Program
    • Identify high-performers at year 2.5
    • Accelerated promotion pathway (target 3-year cycle vs. 4-5 year)
  2. Enhanced Stock Options
    • LASSO identified stock options as strong protective factor
    • Expand eligibility to employees at 3+ years tenure
    • Vesting schedule tied to 4-year retention

Expected Impact: Reduce proportion of 4+ year stagnation from 15% to 10%, preventing 25-30 annual departures.
ROI: $1.25M-$1.5M annual savings (assuming $50K replacement cost).

Priority 3: Department-Specific Interventions (Medium-term - Months 3-12)

Sales Department (HIGHEST ATTRITION: 20.6%)

Actions: 1. Territory Optimization - Rebalance account assignments - Reduce travel requirements where possible - Clarify commission structures

  1. Sales Enablement Resources
    • Improve CRM systems
    • Provide ongoing training
    • Enhance marketing support
  2. Environment Improvements
    • Modern sales tools
    • Quiet spaces for phone calls
    • Recognition programs (not relationship-building - that’s not significant for Sales)

Expected Impact: Reduce Sales attrition from 20.6% to 16% (overall average), preventing 20-25 annual departures in Sales.

R&D Department (Maintain Excellence)

Actions: 1. Continue holistic satisfaction focus 2. Invest in challenging projects 3. Foster collaborative culture 4. Maintain current retention programs

HR Department (Diagnostic Phase)

Actions: 1. Conduct qualitative exit interviews (sample too small for quantitative insights) 2. Benchmark against other professional service departments 3. Revisit in 12 months with larger sample

Expected Impact for all Priority 3: 20-30 fewer annual departures.

1.4.3 Overall Expected ROI

Combined Intervention Impact:

Priority Prevented Departures Cost Savings Investment
Overtime Mgmt 35-40 $1.75M-$2.0M $15K
Career Dev 25-30 $1.25M-$1.5M $50K
Dept-Specific 20-30 $1.0M-$1.5M $80K
TOTAL 80-100 $4.0M-$5.0M $145K

Net ROI: $3.85M-$4.85M annual savings for $145K investment = 27-33x return in Year 1 alone.

1.5 Limitations & Future Work (2 minutes)

GREG: “Like any analysis, ours has limitations:

1.5.1 Data Limitations

  1. Synthetic Dataset
    • IBM simulated this data for teaching purposes
    • While realistic, patterns may not perfectly mirror actual company data
    • Mitigation: All methodologies are sound and transferable to real datasets
  2. Class Imbalance (16.1% attrition)
    • Limited minority class samples
    • Mitigation: Used weighted models, threshold optimization, stratified sampling
  3. Cross-Sectional Design
    • Cannot establish causality, only association
    • We don’t know if low satisfaction causes attrition or if employees who plan to leave report low satisfaction
    • Mitigation: Focus on actionable patterns regardless of causal direction
  4. Missing Exit Reasons
    • Don’t know if departures were voluntary (resignations) vs. involuntary (terminations)
    • Future Work: If available, stratify analysis by exit type

1.5.2 Methodological Limitations

  1. Small HR Sample (n=63)
    • Limits statistical power for Q3 HR analysis
    • Future Work: Combine HR with other professional services for larger sample
  2. No Time Series
    • Can’t track satisfaction changes over time
    • Future Work: Implement quarterly satisfaction surveys; build survival analysis models
  3. Limited to Satisfaction Variables in Q3
    • Q3 only examined satisfaction; didn’t include overtime, promotion, etc. in department models
    • Future Work: Build full multivariate models stratified by department

1.6 Technical Q&A Preparation

GREG: Here are key technical points I might be asked:

1.6.1 Q: “Why use stratified models instead of one model with Department as a predictor?”

A: “Great question. We could have built one model:

Attrition ~ Satisfaction + Department + Satisfaction*Department

But stratified models offer key advantages:

  1. Different Coefficient Sets: R&D JobSatisfaction = -0.512, Sales JobSatisfaction = -0.623. These aren’t just different intercepts - the slopes differ.

  2. Sample Size Transparency: By modeling separately, we explicitly show that HR (n=63) has limited power, whereas in a pooled model this would be hidden.

  3. Practical Implementation: HR managers can focus on their department’s model without worrying about reference coding or interaction term interpretation.

  4. Model Assumptions: Stratified models don’t assume parallel effects. Sales may have fundamentally different attrition mechanisms than R&D.

That said, a pooled model with interactions would be valid too - it’s a tradeoff between flexibility (stratified) and power (pooled).”

1.6.2 Q: “Your AUC values are only 0.68-0.78. Isn’t that low?”

A: “Context is crucial here. Predicting human behavior is inherently difficult - we’re not predicting physical laws.

Benchmarks: - AUC = 0.5 → Random guessing - AUC = 0.7 → Acceptable performance - AUC = 0.8 → Good performance - AUC = 0.9 → Excellent (rare in social sciences)

Our Random Forest achieved AUC = 0.777, which is good performance for a behavioral prediction task.

Industry Comparison: Published HR attrition studies typically report AUC values of 0.70-0.80. We’re in that range.

Practical Value: At AUC = 0.777, if we flag the top 20% highest-risk employees: - We’ll capture approximately 45-50% of actual future leavers - This is actionable - HR can focus retention efforts on this segment

Perfect prediction (AUC = 1.0) is unrealistic because: - Employees have personal reasons we can’t measure (spouse job relocation, health issues) - Life events are unpredictable - Some attrition is healthy organizational turnover

Our models provide meaningful risk stratification despite not being perfect.”

1.6.3 Q: “Why didn’t you use neural networks or more advanced methods?”

A: “Excellent question. We deliberately chose interpretable models for three reasons:

1. Business Stakeholder Communication: - HR managers need to understand why an employee is flagged as high-risk - “This employee has OverTime=Yes and 5 years without promotion” is actionable - A neural network produces a black-box prediction HR can’t explain or act upon

2. Limited Sample Size: - We have 1,470 employees total, only 237 with attrition - Neural networks need thousands to tens of thousands of examples to avoid overfitting - Our sample size is perfect for logistic regression, decision trees, and random forests

3. Feature Engineering Matters More: - With structured tabular data (not images/text), feature quality >> model complexity - Our interaction terms (e.g., Promotion*Income) capture non-linearities - Careful variable selection via LASSO provides feature quality

Performance Comparison: Published studies comparing neural networks to random forests on similar HR datasets show minimal AUC improvement (typically 0.01-0.03), not worth the loss of interpretability.

That said, if this were a massive dataset (100K+ employees), neural networks or gradient boosting would be worth exploring.”

1.6.4 Q: “How did you handle the limited HR department sample size?”

A: “The n=63 HR sample is a legitimate limitation. Here’s how we addressed it:

What We Did: 1. Acknowledged the limitation explicitly in our report 2. Reported wide confidence intervals - showed that non-significance is likely a power issue, not a true null effect 3. Compared model fit metrics (AIC, AUC) across departments to show HR model is less reliable 4. Recommended qualitative research for HR since quantitative analysis is underpowered

What We Didn’t Do: - We didn’t pool HR with other departments (would hide the issue) - We didn’t drop HR entirely (they still have 19% attrition rate worth investigating) - We didn’t overinterpret non-significant results

Alternative Approaches: 1. Bayesian Inference: Could use informative priors from R&D/Sales to borrow strength 2. Bootstrap Confidence Intervals: Could better quantify uncertainty 3. Exact Logistic Regression: Could handle small samples better than standard asymptotics

But for an educational project, acknowledging the limitation and recommending qualitative follow-up is the most honest approach.

Future Work: If we had multi-year data, we could pool HR across years (e.g., 3 years * 63 employees = 189 observations) for better power.”

1.7 Closing Statement (1 minute)

GREG: “To summarize:

We’ve built a comprehensive attrition prediction system that identifies high-risk employees with 78% accuracy. More importantly, we’ve translated these predictions into actionable HR strategies:

✓ Overtime monitoring can prevent 35-40 annual departures
✓ Career acceleration can prevent 25-30 annual departures
✓ Department-specific programs can prevent 20-30 annual departures

Combined impact: 80-100 fewer departures annually, saving $4-5 million for a $145K investment.

Beyond the numbers, we’ve demonstrated how statistical modeling informs targeted interventions rather than wasteful one-size-fits-all programs.

Thank you for your attention. Rupesh and I are happy to answer any questions.”

1.8 Additional Q&A Points

1.8.1 Q: “What would you do differently if you had more time?”

GREG: “Four extensions:

  1. Survival Analysis: Instead of binary attrition (Yes/No), model time-to-attrition. Some employees might be high-risk but won’t leave for 6-12 months. Survival models capture this dynamic.

  2. Cost-Sensitive Learning: Weight prediction errors by cost. False negatives (missing an attrition) cost $50K+ in replacement; false positives (unnecessary retention efforts) cost less. Optimize for business cost, not statistical accuracy.

  3. Sequential Model Development: Build a two-stage model: (1) Predict attrition risk, (2) Among high-risk employees, predict which interventions work best (overtime reduction vs. promotion vs. salary increase).

  4. External Data Integration: Link to labor market data (unemployment rates, industry salary benchmarks) and individual performance data (promotability scores, project success metrics).

  5. Time Series: Track satisfaction over quarters. Someone whose satisfaction dropped from 4 to 2 is higher risk than someone consistently at 2.”

1.8.2 Q: “How would you deploy this model in production?”

GREG: “Deployment roadmap:

Phase 1: Batch Scoring (Months 1-3) - Run model quarterly on full employee base - Generate risk scores (0-1 probability) - Flag top 20% for HR manager review - Integrate into existing HRIS system

Phase 2: Interactive Dashboard (Months 3-6) - Build Tableau/PowerBI dashboard for HR managers - Show department-level risk distributions - Allow filtering by tenure, role, manager - Provide drill-down to individual employees

Phase 3: Real-Time Monitoring (Months 6-12) - Integrate with time-tracking system (detect overtime) - Integrate with HRIS (detect promotion delays) - Trigger alerts when employee crosses risk threshold - Send automated notifications to managers

Phase 4: Intervention Tracking (Ongoing) - Record which interventions were applied - Measure intervention effectiveness - Retrain models quarterly with new data - A/B test intervention strategies

Technical Stack: - Model: Python/R model exported to production - Storage: SQL database for employee data - API: REST API for real-time scoring - Dashboard: Tableau/PowerBI for visualization - Monitoring: Track model drift monthly

Governance: - Privacy: Anonymize data at individual level for analysts - Transparency: Explain model predictions to employees - Ethics: Human override - manager makes final call, not algorithm”

[END OF GREG’S PORTION]

Source Code
# STAT 515 Final Project Presentation Script - GREG SEAN

## Transition from Rupesh (30 seconds)

**GREG:** "Thank you, Rupesh. We've seen that overtime work and career stagnation are major attrition drivers. But do these factors affect all departments equally? That's what our third research question addresses.

---

## Question 3: Department-Stratified Satisfaction Analysis (5-6 minutes)

**GREG:** "Our third research question asks: Do satisfaction variables predict attrition differently across departments? Should HR implement department-specific retention strategies?

### Why Stratify by Department?

Organizations often apply one-size-fits-all retention programs, but this ignores fundamental differences in job characteristics:

- **R&D Engineers:** Creative problem-solving, collaborative projects, technical challenges
- **Sales Representatives:** Client-facing, commission-driven, high-pressure targets
- **HR Professionals:** People-focused, policy implementation, organizational support

These distinct roles likely have different satisfaction drivers and attrition patterns.

### Key Variables (Q3)
- **JobSatisfaction:** Satisfaction with role/responsibilities (1-4 scale)
- **EnvironmentSatisfaction:** Satisfaction with work environment (1-4 scale)
- **RelationshipSatisfaction:** Satisfaction with colleagues/manager (1-4 scale)
- **Department:** R&D, Sales, or HR

### Methodology: Stratified Logistic Regression

We fit separate logistic regression models for each department:

```
Model: Attrition ~ JobSatisfaction + EnvironmentSatisfaction + RelationshipSatisfaction
Separate models for: R&D, Sales, HR
```

This approach allows:
- Different coefficient estimates per department
- Department-specific effect sizes
- Tailored insights for targeted interventions

### Department Breakdown

**Research & Development (R&D):**
- Sample size: 961 employees (65% of dataset)
- Attrition rate: 13.8% (lowest)
- Most stable department

**Sales:**
- Sample size: 446 employees (30% of dataset)
- Attrition rate: 20.6% (highest)
- Highest turnover challenge

**Human Resources (HR):**
- Sample size: 63 employees (4% of dataset)
- Attrition rate: 19.0%
- Limited statistical power due to small sample

### Key Findings (Q3)

**1. R&D Department (n=961, 13.8% attrition)**

All three satisfaction measures are statistically significant predictors:

- **JobSatisfaction:** Coefficient = -0.512 (p < 0.001)
  - Odds Ratio = 0.60 → Each 1-point increase in job satisfaction reduces attrition odds by 40%
  
- **EnvironmentSatisfaction:** Coefficient = -0.487 (p < 0.001)
  - Odds Ratio = 0.61 → Each 1-point increase reduces attrition odds by 39%
  
- **RelationshipSatisfaction:** Coefficient = -0.384 (p < 0.01)
  - Odds Ratio = 0.68 → Each 1-point increase reduces attrition odds by 32%

**Model Performance:** AUC = 0.706

**Interpretation:** R&D employees are highly sensitive to satisfaction levels across all dimensions. This makes sense - engineers and scientists value intellectual stimulation (job), collaborative environment (environment), and peer relationships (relationship).

---

**2. Sales Department (n=446, 20.6% attrition)**

Only two satisfaction measures are significant:

- **JobSatisfaction:** Coefficient = -0.623 (p < 0.01)
  - Odds Ratio = 0.54 → Each 1-point increase reduces attrition odds by 46%
  
- **EnvironmentSatisfaction:** Coefficient = -0.498 (p < 0.05)
  - Odds Ratio = 0.61 → Each 1-point increase reduces attrition odds by 39%
  
- **RelationshipSatisfaction:** Coefficient = -0.201 (p = 0.24) - **NOT SIGNIFICANT**

**Model Performance:** AUC = 0.679

**Interpretation:** Sales representatives care primarily about role fit (job satisfaction) and work conditions (environment), but relationships with colleagues matter less. This aligns with sales culture - individual performance, commission structures, and client relationships dominate. Internal peer relationships are secondary.

**Critical Insight:** Sales has the **highest attrition rate (20.6%)** - this department requires immediate attention.

---

**3. HR Department (n=63, 19.0% attrition)**

None of the satisfaction predictors reach statistical significance:

- **JobSatisfaction:** Coefficient = -0.472 (p = 0.19)
- **EnvironmentSatisfaction:** Coefficient = -0.289 (p = 0.38)
- **RelationshipSatisfaction:** Coefficient = -0.156 (p = 0.66)

**Model Performance:** AUC = 0.682

**Interpretation:** The lack of significance is likely due to **limited sample size (n=63)**. With only 12 attrition cases in HR (19% of 63), we have insufficient statistical power to detect effects. The coefficient directions are negative (protective against attrition), but confidence intervals are too wide for significance.

---

### Comparative Analysis Across Departments

**Coefficient Comparison (Figure 11):**
Our visualization shows:

- **R&D:** All three coefficients are strongly negative and significant
- **Sales:** Job and Environment coefficients are negative; Relationship is near zero
- **HR:** All coefficients are negative but with wide confidence intervals

**Model Performance Table (Table 9):**

| Department | N   | Attrition Rate | AIC    | AUC   |
|-----------|-----|---------------|--------|-------|
| R&D       | 961 | 13.8%         | 643.71 | 0.706 |
| Sales     | 446 | 20.6%         | 355.88 | 0.679 |
| HR        | 63  | 19.0%         | 58.23  | 0.682 |

**Key Observations:**
1. R&D has best model performance (highest AUC) due to large sample and clear satisfaction-attrition relationships
2. Sales has worst attrition rate (20.6%) but moderate model performance
3. HR has smallest sample, limiting both power and model reliability

---

### Practical Implications (Q3)

**Department-Specific Retention Strategies:**

**For R&D (13.8% attrition):**
- **Focus:** All-around satisfaction improvement
- **Actions:**
  - Enhance project variety and technical challenges (job satisfaction)
  - Invest in modern tools and collaborative spaces (environment satisfaction)
  - Foster team-building and mentorship programs (relationship satisfaction)
- **Why:** R&D shows significant effects across all three dimensions

**For Sales (20.6% attrition - HIGHEST PRIORITY):**
- **Focus:** Role clarity and work conditions
- **Actions:**
  - Realign territories and commission structures (job satisfaction)
  - Provide CRM tools, sales training, and support resources (environment satisfaction)
  - De-prioritize team-building initiatives (relationship satisfaction not significant)
- **Why:** Sales attrition is double that of R&D; focus resources where they matter most

**For HR (19.0% attrition):**
- **Focus:** Broader diagnostic needed
- **Actions:**
  - Conduct qualitative exit interviews
  - Analyze non-satisfaction factors (compensation, career path, workload)
  - Consider merging with broader "professional services" category for future analysis
- **Why:** Small sample limits quantitative insights; need qualitative data

---

## Comprehensive Model Comparison (3-4 minutes)

**GREG:** "Now let's step back and compare all eight models we've built across the three research questions.

### Model Performance Summary

| Model                          | AUC   | Type       |
|-------------------------------|-------|------------|
| **Random Forest (Q1)**        | 0.777 | Tree-Based |
| Weighted Logistic (Q2)        | 0.752 | Logistic   |
| LASSO Logistic (Q2)           | 0.747 | Logistic   |
| Unweighted Logistic (Q2)      | 0.732 | Logistic   |
| Stratified LR - R&D (Q3)      | 0.706 | Stratified |
| Decision Tree (Q1)            | 0.685 | Tree-Based |
| Stratified LR - HR (Q3)       | 0.682 | Stratified |
| Stratified LR - Sales (Q3)    | 0.679 | Stratified |

### Model Type Performance

**Tree-Based Models:**
- Mean AUC: 0.731
- Range: 0.685 - 0.777
- Best overall performer: Random Forest

**Logistic Models:**
- Mean AUC: 0.744
- Range: 0.732 - 0.752
- Consistent performance across variants

**Stratified Models:**
- Mean AUC: 0.689
- Range: 0.679 - 0.706
- Lower AUC due to smaller samples per department

### Which Model to Use When?

**For Maximum Prediction Accuracy:**
→ **Use Random Forest (AUC = 0.777)**
- Best for automated early-warning systems
- Identifies at-risk employees with highest accuracy
- Deploy for production prediction tasks

**For Business Interpretability:**
→ **Use Weighted Logistic Regression (AUC = 0.752)**
- Provides clear coefficient interpretations
- "Each year without promotion increases odds by 13%" → actionable insight
- Stakeholders can understand and trust the model logic

**For Variable Selection:**
→ **Use LASSO (AUC = 0.747)**
- Automatically identifies most important predictors
- Reduces 16 candidates to 14 essential variables
- Good balance of performance and parsimony

**For Targeted Interventions:**
→ **Use Department-Stratified Models**
- Different coefficients per department
- Enables tailored retention programs
- Lower AUC acceptable when specificity matters more than aggregate accuracy

---

## Overall Conclusions & Recommendations (3-4 minutes)

**GREG:** "Let me synthesize our key findings and provide actionable recommendations.

### Summary of Key Findings

**Across all three research questions, we found:**

1. **OverTime is the Single Strongest Predictor**
   - 30.5% attrition for overtime workers vs. 10.4% for non-overtime
   - Appears in top predictors across multiple models
   - Effect is consistent across departments

2. **Career Stagnation Has Threshold Effects**
   - Each year without promotion increases attrition odds by 13%
   - Risk accelerates non-linearly: 4+ years = critical threshold
   - Stock options provide strong protective effect

3. **Department Differences Are Substantial**
   - R&D: 13.8% attrition, sensitive to all satisfaction dimensions
   - Sales: 20.6% attrition, sensitive to job/environment only
   - HR: 19.0% attrition, limited sample power

4. **Model Performance Varies by Purpose**
   - Random Forest: Best accuracy (AUC = 0.777)
   - Weighted Logistic: Best interpretability (AUC = 0.752)
   - LASSO: Best parsimony (AUC = 0.747)

### Comprehensive HR Recommendations

**Priority 1: Overtime Management (Immediate - Weeks 1-4)**

**Current State:** 30% of employees work overtime; 30.5% attrition rate in this group.

**Actions:**
1. **Workload Monitoring Dashboard**
   - Track weekly hours in real-time
   - Flag employees exceeding 45 hours for 3+ consecutive weeks
   - Estimated cost: $15,000 for software implementation

2. **Workload Rebalancing Protocol**
   - Quarterly capacity planning meetings
   - Redistribute work across team members
   - Hire temporary contractors during peak periods

3. **Flexible Scheduling Policy**
   - Allow compressed work weeks
   - Enable remote work for 2-3 days/week (reduces overtime and commute burden)

**Expected Impact:** Reduce overtime prevalence from 30% to 20%, preventing 35-40 annual departures.  
**ROI:** Assuming average replacement cost of $50,000/employee, this saves $1.75M-$2M annually vs. $15K investment = 116x return.

---

**Priority 2: Career Development Acceleration (Short-term - Months 1-6)**

**Current State:** 15% of employees at 4+ years without promotion; 13% increased odds per year.

**Actions:**
1. **Mandatory Career Review at Year 3**
   - Individual development plans
   - Promotion eligibility assessment
   - Lateral move opportunities if vertical promotion unavailable

2. **Fast-Track Program**
   - Identify high-performers at year 2.5
   - Accelerated promotion pathway (target 3-year cycle vs. 4-5 year)

3. **Enhanced Stock Options**
   - LASSO identified stock options as strong protective factor
   - Expand eligibility to employees at 3+ years tenure
   - Vesting schedule tied to 4-year retention

**Expected Impact:** Reduce proportion of 4+ year stagnation from 15% to 10%, preventing 25-30 annual departures.  
**ROI:** $1.25M-$1.5M annual savings (assuming $50K replacement cost).

---

**Priority 3: Department-Specific Interventions (Medium-term - Months 3-12)**

**Sales Department (HIGHEST ATTRITION: 20.6%)**

**Actions:**
1. **Territory Optimization**
   - Rebalance account assignments
   - Reduce travel requirements where possible
   - Clarify commission structures

2. **Sales Enablement Resources**
   - Improve CRM systems
   - Provide ongoing training
   - Enhance marketing support

3. **Environment Improvements**
   - Modern sales tools
   - Quiet spaces for phone calls
   - Recognition programs (not relationship-building - that's not significant for Sales)

**Expected Impact:** Reduce Sales attrition from 20.6% to 16% (overall average), preventing 20-25 annual departures in Sales.

**R&D Department (Maintain Excellence)**

**Actions:**
1. Continue holistic satisfaction focus
2. Invest in challenging projects
3. Foster collaborative culture
4. Maintain current retention programs

**HR Department (Diagnostic Phase)**

**Actions:**
1. Conduct qualitative exit interviews (sample too small for quantitative insights)
2. Benchmark against other professional service departments
3. Revisit in 12 months with larger sample

**Expected Impact for all Priority 3:** 20-30 fewer annual departures.

---

### Overall Expected ROI

**Combined Intervention Impact:**

| Priority | Prevented Departures | Cost Savings | Investment |
|----------|---------------------|-------------|-----------|
| Overtime Mgmt | 35-40 | $1.75M-$2.0M | $15K |
| Career Dev | 25-30 | $1.25M-$1.5M | $50K |
| Dept-Specific | 20-30 | $1.0M-$1.5M | $80K |
| **TOTAL** | **80-100** | **$4.0M-$5.0M** | **$145K** |

**Net ROI:** $3.85M-$4.85M annual savings for $145K investment = **27-33x return in Year 1 alone**.

---

## Limitations & Future Work (2 minutes)

**GREG:** "Like any analysis, ours has limitations:

### Data Limitations

1. **Synthetic Dataset**
   - IBM simulated this data for teaching purposes
   - While realistic, patterns may not perfectly mirror actual company data
   - **Mitigation:** All methodologies are sound and transferable to real datasets

2. **Class Imbalance (16.1% attrition)**
   - Limited minority class samples
   - **Mitigation:** Used weighted models, threshold optimization, stratified sampling

3. **Cross-Sectional Design**
   - Cannot establish causality, only association
   - We don't know if low satisfaction *causes* attrition or if employees who plan to leave *report* low satisfaction
   - **Mitigation:** Focus on actionable patterns regardless of causal direction

4. **Missing Exit Reasons**
   - Don't know if departures were voluntary (resignations) vs. involuntary (terminations)
   - **Future Work:** If available, stratify analysis by exit type

### Methodological Limitations

1. **Small HR Sample (n=63)**
   - Limits statistical power for Q3 HR analysis
   - **Future Work:** Combine HR with other professional services for larger sample

2. **No Time Series**
   - Can't track satisfaction changes over time
   - **Future Work:** Implement quarterly satisfaction surveys; build survival analysis models

3. **Limited to Satisfaction Variables in Q3**
   - Q3 only examined satisfaction; didn't include overtime, promotion, etc. in department models
   - **Future Work:** Build full multivariate models stratified by department

---

## Technical Q&A Preparation

**GREG:** Here are key technical points I might be asked:

### Q: "Why use stratified models instead of one model with Department as a predictor?"

**A:** "Great question. We could have built one model:
```
Attrition ~ Satisfaction + Department + Satisfaction*Department
```

But stratified models offer key advantages:

1. **Different Coefficient Sets:** R&D JobSatisfaction = -0.512, Sales JobSatisfaction = -0.623. These aren't just different intercepts - the slopes differ.

2. **Sample Size Transparency:** By modeling separately, we explicitly show that HR (n=63) has limited power, whereas in a pooled model this would be hidden.

3. **Practical Implementation:** HR managers can focus on their department's model without worrying about reference coding or interaction term interpretation.

4. **Model Assumptions:** Stratified models don't assume parallel effects. Sales may have fundamentally different attrition mechanisms than R&D.

That said, a pooled model with interactions would be valid too - it's a tradeoff between flexibility (stratified) and power (pooled)."

---

### Q: "Your AUC values are only 0.68-0.78. Isn't that low?"

**A:** "Context is crucial here. Predicting human behavior is inherently difficult - we're not predicting physical laws.

**Benchmarks:**
- AUC = 0.5 → Random guessing
- AUC = 0.7 → Acceptable performance
- AUC = 0.8 → Good performance
- AUC = 0.9 → Excellent (rare in social sciences)

Our Random Forest achieved AUC = 0.777, which is **good performance** for a behavioral prediction task.

**Industry Comparison:** Published HR attrition studies typically report AUC values of 0.70-0.80. We're in that range.

**Practical Value:** At AUC = 0.777, if we flag the top 20% highest-risk employees:
- We'll capture approximately 45-50% of actual future leavers
- This is actionable - HR can focus retention efforts on this segment

Perfect prediction (AUC = 1.0) is unrealistic because:
- Employees have personal reasons we can't measure (spouse job relocation, health issues)
- Life events are unpredictable
- Some attrition is healthy organizational turnover

Our models provide meaningful risk stratification despite not being perfect."

---

### Q: "Why didn't you use neural networks or more advanced methods?"

**A:** "Excellent question. We deliberately chose interpretable models for three reasons:

**1. Business Stakeholder Communication:**
- HR managers need to understand *why* an employee is flagged as high-risk
- "This employee has OverTime=Yes and 5 years without promotion" is actionable
- A neural network produces a black-box prediction HR can't explain or act upon

**2. Limited Sample Size:**
- We have 1,470 employees total, only 237 with attrition
- Neural networks need thousands to tens of thousands of examples to avoid overfitting
- Our sample size is perfect for logistic regression, decision trees, and random forests

**3. Feature Engineering Matters More:**
- With structured tabular data (not images/text), feature quality >> model complexity
- Our interaction terms (e.g., Promotion*Income) capture non-linearities
- Careful variable selection via LASSO provides feature quality

**Performance Comparison:** Published studies comparing neural networks to random forests on similar HR datasets show minimal AUC improvement (typically 0.01-0.03), not worth the loss of interpretability.

That said, if this were a massive dataset (100K+ employees), neural networks or gradient boosting would be worth exploring."

---

### Q: "How did you handle the limited HR department sample size?"

**A:** "The n=63 HR sample is a legitimate limitation. Here's how we addressed it:

**What We Did:**
1. **Acknowledged the limitation** explicitly in our report
2. **Reported wide confidence intervals** - showed that non-significance is likely a power issue, not a true null effect
3. **Compared model fit metrics** (AIC, AUC) across departments to show HR model is less reliable
4. **Recommended qualitative research** for HR since quantitative analysis is underpowered

**What We Didn't Do:**
- We didn't pool HR with other departments (would hide the issue)
- We didn't drop HR entirely (they still have 19% attrition rate worth investigating)
- We didn't overinterpret non-significant results

**Alternative Approaches:**
1. **Bayesian Inference:** Could use informative priors from R&D/Sales to borrow strength
2. **Bootstrap Confidence Intervals:** Could better quantify uncertainty
3. **Exact Logistic Regression:** Could handle small samples better than standard asymptotics

But for an educational project, acknowledging the limitation and recommending qualitative follow-up is the most honest approach.

**Future Work:** If we had multi-year data, we could pool HR across years (e.g., 3 years * 63 employees = 189 observations) for better power."

---

## Closing Statement (1 minute)

**GREG:** "To summarize:

**We've built a comprehensive attrition prediction system** that identifies high-risk employees with 78% accuracy. More importantly, we've translated these predictions into actionable HR strategies:

✓ **Overtime monitoring** can prevent 35-40 annual departures  
✓ **Career acceleration** can prevent 25-30 annual departures  
✓ **Department-specific programs** can prevent 20-30 annual departures  

**Combined impact: 80-100 fewer departures annually, saving $4-5 million for a $145K investment.**

Beyond the numbers, we've demonstrated how statistical modeling informs targeted interventions rather than wasteful one-size-fits-all programs.

Thank you for your attention. Rupesh and I are happy to answer any questions."

---

## Additional Q&A Points

### Q: "What would you do differently if you had more time?"

**GREG:** "Four extensions:

1. **Survival Analysis:** Instead of binary attrition (Yes/No), model time-to-attrition. Some employees might be high-risk but won't leave for 6-12 months. Survival models capture this dynamic.

2. **Cost-Sensitive Learning:** Weight prediction errors by cost. False negatives (missing an attrition) cost $50K+ in replacement; false positives (unnecessary retention efforts) cost less. Optimize for business cost, not statistical accuracy.

3. **Sequential Model Development:** Build a two-stage model: (1) Predict attrition risk, (2) Among high-risk employees, predict which interventions work best (overtime reduction vs. promotion vs. salary increase).

4. **External Data Integration:** Link to labor market data (unemployment rates, industry salary benchmarks) and individual performance data (promotability scores, project success metrics).

5. **Time Series:** Track satisfaction over quarters. Someone whose satisfaction dropped from 4 to 2 is higher risk than someone consistently at 2."

---

### Q: "How would you deploy this model in production?"

**GREG:** "Deployment roadmap:

**Phase 1: Batch Scoring (Months 1-3)**
- Run model quarterly on full employee base
- Generate risk scores (0-1 probability)
- Flag top 20% for HR manager review
- Integrate into existing HRIS system

**Phase 2: Interactive Dashboard (Months 3-6)**
- Build Tableau/PowerBI dashboard for HR managers
- Show department-level risk distributions
- Allow filtering by tenure, role, manager
- Provide drill-down to individual employees

**Phase 3: Real-Time Monitoring (Months 6-12)**
- Integrate with time-tracking system (detect overtime)
- Integrate with HRIS (detect promotion delays)
- Trigger alerts when employee crosses risk threshold
- Send automated notifications to managers

**Phase 4: Intervention Tracking (Ongoing)**
- Record which interventions were applied
- Measure intervention effectiveness
- Retrain models quarterly with new data
- A/B test intervention strategies

**Technical Stack:**
- Model: Python/R model exported to production
- Storage: SQL database for employee data
- API: REST API for real-time scoring
- Dashboard: Tableau/PowerBI for visualization
- Monitoring: Track model drift monthly

**Governance:**
- Privacy: Anonymize data at individual level for analysts
- Transparency: Explain model predictions to employees
- Ethics: Human override - manager makes final call, not algorithm"

[END OF GREG'S PORTION]
